969696146112303105.text: Money is a medium. In fact, it is an intermediating phenomenon that biases actions of those who are mediated through its use. 969927355371311105.text: Tokens are representations of value, and different token designs encode different values. One of the fundamental problems with our economy is that the value encoded in the design of our monetary system does not accurately reflect the values of our society.

1120943295344123904.text: Finally, there's a some small easy fixes like explicitly limiting the maximum size of calldata or timestamp, or reserving address space for precompiles – these are things that most clients do anyway, but bugs crawl in the implicit, and explicitness can also help ewasm design!

1120943293842505728.text: The BEGINDATA opcode from EIP615 is also useful on it's own. Contracts compiled with solidity already includes a bunch of junk, errm... I mean _contract metadata_ in unreachable code blocks: https://solidity.readthedocs.io/en/v0.4.25/metadata.html#encoding-of-the-metadata-hash-in-the-bytecode …. BEGINDATA would cleanly separate code from data in EVM bytecode.

1120943292131291138.text: One way of doing this is by starting with unlimited DUPs and SWAPs https://github.com/ethereum/EIPs/pull/663 …, and then change these to become GETLOCAL/PUTLOCAL when subroutines are ready. For those of you that have encountered a "Stack too deep" error when compiling Solidity – EIP-663 is your fix!

1120943290063495175.text:
Everybody's favorite "EVM 1.5" makes a comeback as https://github.com/ethereum/EIPs/blob/master/EIPS/eip-615.md … by @expede and @greg_colvin. 
Static jumps and subroutines opens up new windows for compiler and runtime optimizations, as well as making static analysis easier. Some argue that EIP-615 should be split up:

1120943288331247616.text: Another proposal https://github.com/ethereum/EIPs/blob/98b23466391fa29d631163598f9ee8b71d37f7da/EIPS/eip-1559.md … from Vitalik and @econoar introduces a new mechanism for gas fees: it doubles the block gas limit, while targeting an average of the current 8M via a BASEFEE, common for all txs in a block. While the BASEFEE is burned, miner tips go on toppic.twitter.com/a8vFE8x5UT

1120943287001653253.text: In the meantime, we will likely see some repricing of opcodes. An analysis by @mhswende shows that the increased disk usage has made storage reads a lot slower, making them a signficant bottleneck of block processing. EIP-1884 https://github.com/ethereum/EIPs/blob/master/EIPS/eip-1884.md … quadruples the cost of SLOAD.

1120943284401078272.text:
The proper fix here is arguably state fees, for which a rough plan has been put forth by @realLedgerwatch:
https://ethereum-magicians.org/t/state-fees-formerly-state-rent-pre-eip-proposal-version-3/2654/21 …
This would happen through a series of EIPs, possibly split up into several hard forks. But with EIP deadline fast approaching, we may have to wait...pic.twitter.com/t4U9qJK0ho

Fun to learn, useless to know

1059112613420904448.text: This is fundamentally due to an overreaction to the double spend problem: while some transactions lead to different results depending on the order of their application, most are independent, and we should only ask that the set of transactions are partially ordered. (6)

1059113636617244673.text: Are there data structures with similar compression features to Merkle tress, while remaining their parallell nature? I. e. maintaining a constant representation of state while preserving ways to compare elements for independence in the poset? (8)

1059112735366152192.text: There are multiple examples of data structures in which state updates can be applied concurrently, such as the version control system @pijul_org, and this is of course the goal of many nascent blockchains in development like @rchain_coop and @statebox. (7)

1059112456759455745.text: A more pressing bottleneck however, which the dapp shares with every distributed system which forces a total ordering of state transitions (a set which includes all blockchains live today) is the lack of parallelizability. (5)

1059112369396297728.text: So how does Dai perform in other computational resources? In the current implementation, storage grows linearly with usage to deal with the accounting of user balances and CDPs, but this can in theory easily be replaced with a Merkle root to gain constant on chain storage. (4)

1059112271996166144.text: Even better, computational power increases exponentially with time so now if we set the parameters just right we should be able to construct a system whose real world computational demands remains constant over time, at least until the end of Murphys law. (3)

1059112174373748742.text: Thankfully, the parameter which it is logarithmic in is time, which flows linearly. (2)
